conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the given information and use the properties of an ideal gas and the first law of thermodynamics.

State A: \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \). State B: \( P_B = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), \( V_B = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \). State C: \( P_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), \( V_C = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
The temperature at state A is given as \( T_A = -73^\circ \text{C} \).

premise: Using the ideal gas law: \( P_A V_A = n R T_A \).
conclusion: Calculate the number of moles: \( n = \frac{300}{1662.8} \approx 0.18 \, \text{moles} \).

premise: Calculate work done from A to B: \( W_{AB} = P_A (V_B - V_A) \).
conclusion: Work done from A to B: \( W_{AB} = 900 \, \text{J} \).

premise: Calculate work done from B to C: \( W_{BC} = 0 \).
conclusion: Total work done from A to C: \( W_{AC} = 900 \, \text{J} \).

premise: First law of thermodynamics: \( Q = \Delta U + W \).
Using the ideal gas law for state C: \( P_C V_C = n R T_C \).
conclusion: Calculate temperature at state C: \( T_C \approx 267 \, \text{K} \).
